array.string: Greek colonies sprang up from the Mediterranean to Asia Minor, from North Africa to the coast of the Black Sea. There were more than 1,500 independent city-state.
The Achaemenid Persian Empire first expanded under the leadership of Cyrus the Great, who utilized a strategy of religious and cultural toleration to maintain order.
Siddhartha Gautama, the founder of Buddhism who later became known as “the Buddha,” was born into a wealthy family as a prince in present-day Nepal.
Confucius, also known as Kong Qui or K’ung Fu-tzu, was a Chinese philosopher, teacher and political figure.
This event saw the conquest of Babylon by the Achaemenid Empire under Cyrus the Great and marked the end of the Neo-Babylonian Empire.
Greek democracy created at Athens was direct, rather than representative: any adult male citizen over the age of 20 could take part, and it was a duty to do so
